articles.headline: Toyota to Finance $50 Million ‘Intelligent’ Car Project
articles.snippet: The carmaker will collaborate with Stanford and M.I.T. to focus on using advances in artificial intelligence technologies to make humans better drivers as opposed to developing self-driving vehicles.
articles.abstract: The carmaker will collaborate with Stanford and M.I.T. to focus on using advances in artificial intelligence technologies to make humans better drivers as opposed to developing self-driving vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Toyota Motor Corporation announced on Friday an ambitious $50 million robotics and artificial intelligence research effort, in collaboration with Stanford University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to develop “intelligent” rather than self-driving cars.

articles.headline: Judge’s Ruling Offers Peek Into Private Equity’s Secret World
articles.snippet: A bankruptcy judge in Manhattan ruled that Apax Partners and TPG Capital will go to trial next year over fraud allegations in a 2006 deal involving Hellas Telecommunications.
articles.abstract: A bankruptcy judge in Manhattan ruled that Apax Partners and TPG Capital will go to trial next year over fraud allegations in a 2006 deal involving Hellas Telecommunications.
articles.lead_paragraph: Infiltrating the supersecret world of private equity is difficult, so any glimpse into how these firms operate is worth highlighting.

articles.headline: The Many Pitfalls of Private Student Loans
articles.snippet: Federal loans for education often offer options to ease onerous repayment terms. Not so with private loans, as some borrowers have learned to their dismay.
articles.abstract: Federal loans for education often offer options to ease onerous repayment terms. Not so with private loans, as some borrowers have learned to their dismay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mallory Rego, the first member of her family to attend college, says she now sees that she put too much blind faith in the power of education.

articles.headline: New Type of Drug-Free Labels for Meat Has U.S.D.A. Blessing
articles.snippet: Consumers will soon see the phrase “produced without ractopamine,” which helps add muscle to animals, on packages of some pork products.
articles.abstract: Consumers will soon see the phrase “produced without ractopamine,” which helps add muscle to animals, on packages of some pork products.
articles.lead_paragraph: As meat companies scramble to eliminate antibiotics from their products to address consumer and regulatory concerns, the federal Agriculture Department has quietly opened a new front in the debate over the use of drugs in the livestock and poultry industries.

articles.headline: Iowans Question G.O.P. Talk on Illegal Immigration
articles.snippet: Farms and factories in eastern Iowa have long been a draw for immigrants, and many argue that a one-size-fits-all approach to immigration reform might not work.
articles.abstract: Farms and factories in eastern Iowa have long been a draw for immigrants, and many argue that a one-size-fits-all approach to immigration reform might not work.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Like many voters in Iowa, Ben Hoopes has been listening closely to all the tough talk about illegal immigration coming from the Republican presidential candidates who have crisscrossed his state every week.

articles.headline: Bank of America Board Under Fire for Combining Chairman and Chief Jobs
articles.snippet: Both big public pension funds and influential advisory firms are recommending that shareholders vote against a board proposal that would let Brian Moynihan keep the title of chairman.
articles.abstract: Both big public pension funds and influential advisory firms are recommending that shareholders vote against a board proposal that would let Brian Moynihan keep the title of chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Momentum is building toward forcing Bank of America to undo its decision last year to name the bank’s chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, as chairman as well.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: At West Point, Annual Pillow Fight Becomes Weaponized
articles.snippet: A ritual to let freshmen blow off steam left 30 cadets injured, including 24 with concussions and one with a broken leg.
articles.abstract: A ritual to let freshmen blow off steam left 30 cadets injured, including 24 with concussions and one with a broken leg.
articles.lead_paragraph: For generations, freshmen cadets at the United States Military Academy have marked the end of a grueling summer of training with a huge nighttime pillow fight that is billed as a harmless way to blow off steam and build class spirit.

articles.headline: Russian Moves in Syria Pose Concerns for U.S.
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin has sent a military advance team to Syria and is taking other steps that the United States fears could lead Russia to expand its military support for President Bashar al-Assad, administration officials said.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has sent a military advance team to Syria and is taking other steps that the United States fears could lead Russia to expand its military support for President Bashar al-Assad, administration officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has sent a military advance team to Syria and is taking other steps the United States fears may signal that President Vladimir V. Putin is planning to vastly expand his military support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, administration officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Basketball Arena Battles for San Francisco’s Heart
articles.snippet: The owners of the Golden State Warriors are offering to foot the bill for a new 18,000-seat entertainment complex in San Francisco, but some in the city are crying foul.
articles.abstract: The owners of the Golden State Warriors are offering to foot the bill for a new 18,000-seat entertainment complex in San Francisco, but some in the city are crying foul.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prosperity is the sound of jackhammers and pile drivers in the morning.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Relying on Southern Primaries to Fend Off Rivals
articles.snippet: The Clinton campaign is increasingly devoting resources to win the South Carolina contest while laying the groundwork to sweep other states in the region, advisers said.
articles.abstract: The Clinton campaign is increasingly devoting resources to win the South Carolina contest while laying the groundwork to sweep other states in the region, advisers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign is methodically building a political firewall across the South in hopes of effectively locking up the Democratic nomination in March regardless of any early setbacks in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Germans Welcome Migrants After Long Journey Through Hungary and Austria
articles.snippet: By Saturday evening, some 6,000 migrants had already arrived here, and another 1,800 were expected to arrive in trains overnight, according to the German police.
articles.abstract: By Saturday evening, some 6,000 migrants had already arrived here, and another 1,800 were expected to arrive in trains overnight, according to the German police.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Germans waving welcome signs in German, English and Arabic came to the train station here Saturday to greet the first group of what is expected to be about 8,000 migrants to arrive in Germany by early Sunday, after an arduous and emotional journey through Hungary and Austria.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold, Steven Erlanger and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Food Industry Enlisted Academics in G.M.O. Lobbying War, Emails Show
articles.snippet: Both sides in a fight over genetically modified crops have relied on scientists to lend their authority, while providing financial support in return.
articles.abstract: Both sides in a fight over genetically modified crops have relied on scientists to lend their authority, while providing financial support in return.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At Monsanto, sales of genetically modified seeds were steadily rising. But executives at the company’s St. Louis headquarters were privately worried about attacks on the safety of their products.

articles.headline: Pope Francis’ Visit to U.S. Is His First Ever, for Several Reasons
articles.snippet: Unlike predecessors who traveled to the United States before rising to the papacy, Pope Francis has waited until age 78 to visit the country that thinks of itself as the center of everything.
articles.abstract: Unlike predecessors who traveled to the United States before rising to the papacy, Pope Francis has waited until age 78 to visit the country that thinks of itself as the center of everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his first private meeting with Pope Francis in the Vatican two years ago, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said, the pope took out an atlas with a map of the United States and asked Cardinal Dolan, the archbishop of New York, to point out the various regions and cities and talk about how they differed.

articles.headline: As Europe Grasps for Answers, More Migrants Flood Its Borders
articles.snippet: Despite cheers of welcome in Germany, it remained unclear how Europe would deal with successive waves of people, for months or even years.
articles.abstract: Despite cheers of welcome in Germany, it remained unclear how Europe would deal with successive waves of people, for months or even years.
articles.lead_paragraph: HEGYESHALOM, Hungary — Throughout the day on Sunday, train after packed train arrived at this border town from Budapest, the passengers smoothly shifting to a gleaming Austrian train on the opposite side of the platform and being whisked on to Vienna and beyond — 13,000 of them in the first 36 hours after Hungary allowed throngs of refugees and migrants to travel toward Germany.
articles.byline: By Rick Lyman and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Ousted as Gay, Aging Veterans Are Battling Again for Honorable Discharges
articles.snippet: Emboldened by recent advances for homosexuals in and out of the military, more gay veterans look to have their ousters reclassified.
articles.abstract: Emboldened by recent advances for homosexuals in and out of the military, more gay veterans look to have their ousters reclassified.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — When the Army discharged Pvt. Donald Hallman in 1955 for being what it called a “Class II homosexual,” the 21-year-old was so scared of being an outcast that he burned all his military records, save for a single dog tag he hid away.

articles.headline: Workers Organize, but Don’t Unionize, to Get Protection Under Labor Law
articles.snippet: As unions have weakened, work site committees offer an alternative that is easier to form and can guard workers’ rights and improve job conditions.
articles.abstract: As unions have weakened, work site committees offer an alternative that is easier to form and can guard workers’ rights and improve job conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Jorge Porras used to report to his carwash job here most mornings at 8:15 a.m., but he said that his boss often did not let him clock in until 11, when customers frequently began streaming in. Many days he was paid for just six hours, he said, even though he worked nine and a half hours.

articles.headline: Jeb Bush, Family Ties and a Museum That Never Materialized
articles.snippet: A case of misplaced trust offers a cautionary tale about the downside of the vast network of friends and supporters that has been an essential part of the Bush family’s political success.
articles.abstract: A case of misplaced trust offers a cautionary tale about the downside of the vast network of friends and supporters that has been an essential part of the Bush family’s political success.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — When Jeb Bush set out to build a political base of his own in South Florida three decades ago, he did not lack for new friends. He was a magnet for a long line of Republicans eager to be associated with him and his powerful family, including a Cuban immigrant and former corrections officer named Tony Campos.

articles.headline: Caijing Journalist’s Shaming Signals China’s Growing Control Over News Media
articles.snippet: When a journalist from a reputable publication was compelled to confess on television before going to trial, it came as a surprise to many.
articles.abstract: When a journalist from a reputable publication was compelled to confess on television before going to trial, it came as a surprise to many.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the Chinese Ministry of Public Security arrested nearly 200 people at the end of August for “spreading rumors,” one of the most prominent targets was Wang Xiaolu, a reporter for the respected business magazine Caijing.

articles.headline: New Apple TV Is Said to Focus on Games, Challenging Traditional Consoles
articles.snippet: Vying for a spot in living rooms, Apple — which is expected to announce its new system on Wednesday — may have a tough time luring gamers who use an Xbox One or PlayStation.
articles.abstract: Vying for a spot in living rooms, Apple — which is expected to announce its new system on Wednesday — may have a tough time luring gamers who use an Xbox One or PlayStation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple stumbled into the games business almost by accident not long after it released the iPhone in 2007, igniting a new multibillion-dollar mobile games industry in the process.

articles.headline: The Crowding-Out Effect of Gargantuan Movies
articles.snippet: Ticket sales at North American cinemas rose 10 percent, to $4.48 billion, this summer. But it was a lopsided victory for the studios.
articles.abstract: Ticket sales at North American cinemas rose 10 percent, to $4.48 billion, this summer. But it was a lopsided victory for the studios.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood had one of its best summers ever at the domestic box office, but it was a sharply lopsided victory. Studios either thrived or withered, an outcome that reflects the winner-take-all nature of the mass-appeal movie business.

articles.headline: U.S. Revamping Rebel Force Fighting ISIS in Syria
articles.snippet: The proposed changes come after a Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda attacked the rebel group of the first 54 Syrian graduates of the military program.
articles.abstract: The proposed changes come after a Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda attacked the rebel group of the first 54 Syrian graduates of the military program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an acknowledgment of severe shortcomings in its effort to create a force of moderate rebels to battle the Islamic State in Syria, the Pentagon is drawing up plans to significantly revamp the program by dropping larger numbers of fighters into safer zones as well as providing better intelligence and improving their combat skills.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Melting Ice Isn’t Opening Arctic to Oil Bonanza
articles.snippet: The region remains inhospitable for drilling, while environmental concerns, a sagging market and sanctions against Russia also have impeded plans.
articles.abstract: The region remains inhospitable for drilling, while environmental concerns, a sagging market and sanctions against Russia also have impeded plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: TERIBERKA, Russia — The warming Arctic should already have transformed this impoverished fishing village on the coast of the Barents Sea.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: China, Trying to Bolster Currency, Taps Foreign Reserves
articles.snippet: Despite a record monthly decrease of nearly $100 billion, the nation still has the world’s biggest cache of foreign reserves, government data shows.
articles.abstract: Despite a record monthly decrease of nearly $100 billion, the nation still has the world’s biggest cache of foreign reserves, government data shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China is burning through its huge stockpile of foreign exchange reserves at the fastest pace yet as it seeks to prop up its currency and stem a rising tide of money flowing out of the country.
